head.title: In the Brooklyn Desert, a Cool Sahara

hedline.hl1: In the Brooklyn Desert, a Cool Sahara

abstract.p: Eric Asimov's To Go column on Sahara, Turkish restaurant in Gravesend, Brooklyn, that does thriving takeout business; photo (S)

block.p: THE word Sahara may conjure up images of rolling dunes and head-splitting heat, but in Gravesend, Brooklyn, Sahara is an oasis.

In the summer, this sprawling Turkish restaurant offers a lovely garden in the rear where you can dine like the luckiest of desert dwellers, under trellises thick with grapevines, surrounded by squash and cucumber plants.
THE word Sahara may conjure up images of rolling dunes and head-splitting heat, but in Gravesend, Brooklyn, Sahara is an oasis.

In the summer, this sprawling Turkish restaurant offers a lovely garden in the rear where you can dine like the luckiest of desert dwellers, under trellises thick with grapevines, surrounded by squash and cucumber plants.
But for urban nomads slogging through a New York summer, Sahara offers something even more useful: a thriving takeout business.

Those who have lived with intense heat know best that the way to eat is to eliminate complications. Simple food simply prepared is the secret, and at this Sahara excels. A shepherd's salad ($3.50 medium) is no more than cubed tomatoes and cucumbers mixed with onions, black olives and fragrant parsley, but it is impeccably fresh and refreshing.

Along with a few rounds of puffy pide bread and perhaps some of the sparkling spreads like hummus and baba gannouj ($3 each), or ezme ($3.50), a spicy chopped salad of eggplant, red pepper and other vegetables, it can be a complete meal.

More substantial dishes include expertly grilled chicken thighs ($8) that have been gently marinated and subtly imbued with smoke, or a richly flavored gyro kebab ($7), sliced thin and grilled until crisp around the edges.
Tender baby lamb chops ($13.90) and lamb kebabs ($9.90), both served with buttery rice and a selection of grilled vegetables, are also good choices.
Desserts, like thickly honeyed baklava ($3) and tulumba ($3), small balls of fried dough drenched in syrup, look like standard-issue Middle Eastern sweets.

For a true treat, Mansoura's Middle Eastern Shop, a kosher Sephardic bakery about 10 blocks from Sahara, sells wonderful, delicate pastries, like semolina cake topped with almonds and subtly flavored with rose water ($10 a pound) or richly flavored apricot-and-pistachio logs ($7 a half pound).
Sahara, 2337-2343 Coney Island Avenue, near Avenue T, Gravesend, Brooklyn, (718) 376-8594. Delivery: five-mile radius. Mansoura's, 515 Kings Highway, (718) 645-7977.
